Experience Staff Software Engineer Google November 2013  – Present (1 year 10 months) New York, NY I have returned to Google to help work in improving the efficiency of Google's planet-scale storage systems. This includes reducing human effort required to manage storage and improving the technical efficiency of the systems, preferably both at once. =) Director of Site Reliability Engineering Tumblr February 2013  –  October 2013  (9 months) New York At Tumblr, I helped grow and mature the Site Reliability organization, which was made up of five teams:  
- distributed data: MySQL, Hbase, etc. 
- cluster management: Collins, puppet, package management, etc. 
- traffic/perimeter: haproxy, varnish, nginx, email in/out, etc. 
- network engineering: included both in-datacenter traffic and our external-facing transit, using mostly Juniper EX & MX equipment 
- datacenter technicians: machine/hardware swap & diagnosis, cooling management, hardware ordering & deployment, etc. (This team had a local datacenter manager.) 
 
I also managed vendor relationships for purchasing hardware, leasing colo space (and hardware), content distribution networks, storage, DNS (etc) including several contract renegotiations and escalations of critical issues as well as detailed cost models. 
 
I worked to Improve process around post-mortems and oversaw a period of unprecedented availability (which I can certainly only take partial credit for, if that. =) ) I worked to push all teams to a longer, more detailed horizon of planning to eliminate some chronic failure modes. Staff Site Reliability Engineer Google February 2005  –  February 2013  (8 years 1 month) New York, NY I worked at Google for about 7 years (net of paternity and personal leave), primarily on massive cluster- and planet-scale storage systems. I have been techlead for a team of 25, who focused on the relentless pursuit of efficiency, low retrieval latencies, durability and scale. Toward the end of my time, I worked on more strategic, long-term projects surrounding efficiency and configuration of Google's (machine) resources. Summary I provide technical leadership and manage the SRE team that is involved in designing and maintaining planet scale, highly available, distributed network control systems. These include: 
 
- the software defined network control systems that provide traffic engineering, bandwidth guarantees and isolation for traffic on Google's Backbones (for eg., B4 - http://cseweb.ucsd.edu/~vahdat/papers/b4-sigcomm13.pdf) 
- the virtualized networking stack for Google Cloud (Andromeda - http://googlecloudplatform.blogspot.com/2014/04/enter-andromeda-zone-google-cloud-platforms-latest-networking-stack.html) 
- trans-continental data transfer and placement services that move several PB/day 
- network monitoring, simulation and analysis systems 
 
In a previous role, I was the lead SRE for PicasaWeb (now Google Photos) and managed storage, caching and serving systems. Summary I've served as a Quality Assurance Engineer for the past several years, testing software, writing test cases, and writing automation to implement those test cases (manual testing is evil). In addition to serving in this capacity, I've contributed to several open-source projects, such as Func (http://fedoraproject.org/func), Cobbler (http://fedoraproject.org/cobbler), and Fogmachine (http://github.com/ssalevan/fogmachine), which is a pet project of mine related to cloud computing. 
 
In my spare time, I nurse a sometimes-raging music affliction. I served as WKNC's Local Music Director/Czar for around 5 years, I ran a record label (we called ourselves Neckbeard Records), and I play the keys in a Talking Heads cover band (we call ourselves... Pundits...).
